qas.question: When did negotiations start to regulate mining in Antarctica?
What group led the fight to prevent mineral development in Antarctica?
When was the treaty to regulate mining agreed upon?
Which two countries refused to ratify the treaty to regulate mineral use in Antarctica?
What was the alternate treaty offered by Australia and France?

plausible_answers.text: the Antarctic Treaty Parties began negotiations on a convention to regulate mining in Antarctica
Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resources

qas.question: What year was the CARMAR adopted?
Who announced they would not ratify the CARMAR?
What was entered into force on 14 January 1983?

context: In <a0_0>1983<a0_0/>, <b5_0>the Antarctic Treaty Parties began negotiations on a convention to regulate mining in Antarctica<b5_0/>. A coalition of international organizations launched a public pressure campaign to prevent any minerals development in the region, led largely by <a1_0>Greenpeace International,<a1_0/> which established its own scientific station—World Park Base—in the Ross Sea region and conducted annual expeditions to document environmental effects of humans on Antarctica. In <a2_0><b7_0>1988<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the <b6_0>Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resources<b6_0/> (CRAMRA) was adopted. The following year, however, <a3_0><b8_0>Australia and France<b8_0/><a3_0/> announced that they would not ratify the convention, rendering it dead for all intents and purposes. They proposed instead that a comprehensive regime to protect the Antarctic environment be negotiated in its place. The Protocol on Environmental Protection to the <b9_0>Antarctic Treaty<b9_0/> (the "<a4_0>Madrid Protocol<a4_0/>") was negotiated as other countries followed suit and on 14 January 1998 it entered into force. The Madrid Protocol bans all mining in Antarctica, designating Antarctica a "natural reserve devoted to peace and science".
